review: This movie was one of the worst horror movies I've ever seen. If it was meant to be a horror comedy, then it would fend as OK but just as a horror movie, my god, I really felt like I wasted my time. The whole time I watched it, I laughed and then thought to myself "What in the...f?", because of how ridiculous this movie was. It was only scary in the sense of the pop-ups but then turned into something laughable!! It was an entertaining movie, I'd say to watch it with friends on a movie night, you'll have a lot of laughs and fun times at how ridiculous this movie is. But don't expect a great horror movie, expect a good-time horror-comedy. (Still not sure if it was meant to be comedic or not).

title: Oral Fetish
review:
A fly, a dirty napkin and even an old lady's hand, - all those things at some point of the movie happened to be in the main protagonist's, Christine Brown's, mouth.

This is a mediocre horror movie with a bunch of jump scares and bad writing. Seriously, the girl claims that she's a vegetarian and lactose intolerant, next thing you know she's bringing a goose cake to a party and stuffing her face with ice cream like some kind of Bridget Jones.

And yeah, get ready to see a bunch of stuff coming in and out of people's mouths in this movie. I'm not sure who told Raimi brothers that this will be scary, but if you enjoyed 2 girls 1 cup you gonna like this one.

5/10, Not scary.

title: another horror
review: it is not different by many other horrors - exercises to use different ingredients for create a decent story. in this case, interesting remains the mixture between cultural influences, a cocktail from Easter influences, Spanish language and Gypsy tradition. so, the pillars are Lorna Raver and Adriana Barraza. but, unfortunately, that is all. because, out of folk references, the film is common, without taste or identity, too much similar by teenager horrors, with chaotic moments and not surprising evolution. sure, the drop of soulless young woman behind revenge of a client seems be not bad idea but Alison Lohman is in search of her character dimension and Justin Long has a not brilliant role. a horror. like many others. not bad. but far to be seductive.

title: Scary, Exciting, Goofily Good Fun Gypsy Curse Horror Flick
review:
Christine Brown is an aspiring banker who refuses to grant credit to an old gypsy woman who can't make her house payments. Big mistake - the nasty old woman places a curse on Christine, and in three days a demon will come to drag her to hell ...

This gleefully nutty and highly enjoyable little horror movie is a groovy return to their roots for Evil Dead auteur Raimi and producer Robert Tapert. It's wonderful to see that a filmmaker can swap a two-hundred-and-fifty million dollar budget back down to a mere thirty million and still have a lot of fun. If the movie has one weakness it's that the story is a little slight, but it has plenty of amusing twists and both the pacing and the character / loony-toon situations are balanced just right. Lohman suffers horrific indignities (usually involving unpleasant things administered orally) but keeps plugging away so we root for her, whilst Raver has a whale of a time as the ever-increasingly horrific Mrs Ganush (her teeth exploits alone are worth seeing). The realisation of the Lamia demon is wonderful as a shadowy goat-like monster who seems to twist reality and enjoy tormenting victims more than capturing them. All its scenes are memorable, especially a hair-curling seance and a hilarious Wile E Coyote setup in Christine's garage. There's also a fabulous score by Christopher Young to accompany these scenes, which is real Old School Orchestral Horror - all Romany violins, choral harmonies, discordant sound and driving rhythms. A good scary movie uses all of cinema's techniques - photography, editing, sound, music - and when done well, as is the case here, is a deliciously exciting and visceral experience. Written by Raimi and his sensible older brother Ivan (who also wrote Darkman and Army Of Darkness) - fans of the director can also spot his trusty 1973 Oldsmobile Delta 88 in a prominent role as Mrs Ganush's car. A great little demonic horror flick, this would make an excellent double-bill with Jacques Tourneur's similarly themed but fifty years older cult classic Night Of The Demon.

title: Best horror movie
review: This is the best horror movie I have seen till now. I must admit it I could not watch it in a single go. Hats off to Raimi for such a great movie. There was not a single scene in the move that did not scare me. I am used to watch horror movies but I just could not watch this movie. Perfect story line, good cast. Perfect photography, effects, sounds kept me jump off my seat till the last scene of the movie as though there was some electric current passing through my seat. I would warn even adults to watch this movie with a great care. People with heart problems please don't watch it. I was waiting to come across such terrifying movies as horror movies now a days does not have much in it. But this 1999 movie even when watched in 2013 where such kind of moves are very common scared me a lot. Really scary..a perfect one for those who say they don't get scared of things.

title: Drag Me to Hell
review: From director Sam Raimi (The Evil Dead, Spider-Man), I was told by someone that this was rubbish, but the critics praised it with four stars out of five, and I was up for a possibly over the top scary movie. Basically, the film opens in 1969 Pasadena, California with a boy being attacked by unseen forces. Medium Shaun San Dena (Flor De Maria Chahua) attempts to stop the evil spirits from dragging him to hell, but she is unsuccessful, the ground opens up with a fiery blaze and the boy is taken, the medium knows she will encounter these forces again. In present day, Christine Brown (Alison Lohman) is bank loan officer hoping for a promotion to assistant manager instead of co-worker Stu Rubin (Reggie Lee), and Jim Jacks (David Paymer), her boss, advises she demonstrates making tough decisions to get it. One day, she encounters elderly woman Sylvia Ganush (Lorna Raver) who wants an extension on her mortgage payment, despite failing to pay it a couple of times. Christine is first empathetic, but decides to deny her request to prove herself to her boss. The woman gets on her knees and begs, but is still denied, and then she attempts to attack Christine and is taken out. In the parking lot, Mrs. Ganush returns and again tries to attack Christine, and during the struggle she tears off a button from Christine's coat, she places a curse on the owner of the coat, i.e. Christine, as revenge, and then she disappears. Christine is concerned for her safety, and despite some criticism from her boyfriend, Clay Dalton (Justin Long), the two of them visit fortune teller Rham Jas (Dileep Rao), and he has a terrifying vision and confirms she has been cursed. Following a horrific attack by an invisible evil force, Christine is shaken up, but returns to work. There, she gets frustrated with Stu and suddenly has a nose bleed, but this turns projectile and soaks her boss in blood, and while she runs away Stu takes an important file that would be likely to get her the promotion. Christine decides to confront Mrs. Ganush at the house to be taken, and have the curse lifted from her, but she finds the old woman has died and a wake is being held. She turns to Rham Jas, he explains that being the owner of the button, powerful demon Lamia will haunt her for the next three days before she will taken to hell. He suggests she could sacrifice an animal to appease the demon. Following another savage attack, and desperate to stop them, she kills her pet kitten, which breaks her heart. Christine has dinner with Clay's parents, father Leonard (Chelcie Ross) and mother Trudy (American Pie's Molly Cheek). There, the spirit still torments her, and frightens the Daltons. Christine again goes to Rham Jas, and he says Shaun San Dena (Adriana Barraza), now elderly, is willing to risk her life and exorcise the demon, but at the price of $10,000. Following more attacks, and knowing she believes strongly in what is happening, Clay pays the fee. The s√©ance goes ahead, the woman manages to pull the demon from Christine's body into her own, the spirit speaking vows it will never stop until Christine dies. The spirit is then transported into a goat, but San Dena's assistant Milos (Kevin Foster) fails to kill it, becoming possessed himself. The s√©ance ends, and San Dena dies in the process, Rham Jas explains the spirit was only banished until the next day. He seals the cursed button in an envelope and says that she could give it to someone else to become their possession, the curse will then pass to that person. Christine thinks of giving it to Stu as revenge for stealing her job, but meeting him being tearful and pathetic she changes her mind. But the fortune teller says it may be possible to eliminate the curse giving the button to a dead body, so she goes to the grave Mrs. Ganush, as "the soul never dies". Despite a torrential downpour, and the dug up grave flooding, she is successful in shoving the envelope in the corpse's mouth before the dawn. The film ends with Christine happy to have been promoted, following Stu explaining that an important file was stolen and Stu has been fired. She buys herself a new coat in celebration, and Clay is waiting at Los Angeles Union Station ready to propose to her. Surprised by her new coat, Stu reveals finding the envelope and cursed button in the car. Christine is horrified and walks backwards, falling onto the tracks, the ground opens up and she is dragged screaming to the fiery depths of hell. Also starring Bojana Novakovic as Ilenka Ganush. Lohman is a good choice to play the lead victim being tortured mentally and psychologically until the truly savage ending, Long is likeable as the non-believer, and Raver as the disgusting old crone attacking and haunting is a character you love to hate. The story is good and traditional with many elements reminding you of a 1950s scary movie, with great stylish music, inventive camera-work, great moments to disgust, especially the old villain and a fly in the girl's stomach, and a fantastic feeling of unending doom and terror, it a great fun supernatural horror thriller. Very good!

title: Drag me out of the Cinema
review: I'm a huge fan of the Evil Dead movies so I was looking forward to seeing this, albeit some time after release. I sat through the first 50 minutes and then gave up. This movie was slow and boring. It starts off with a fairly clich√©d opening scene/back story but I don't mind a bit of clich√© with my popcorn, not all movies are original after all. As the halfway mark of the movie came and went I began to wonder why I was still watching it - even if this movie had the greatest ending of all time, I was going to be too comatose to see it. I don't mind flashbacks, and I don't mind cheesy plots, or faux scares but I DO mind a movie that seems to say 'wait just wait, this is going to be really good' and then never delivers.

title: So bad it's laughable
review:
I really wanted to like this movie, but it is just horrible. I like Justin Long a lot (Accepted is my favourite movie by a long shot), but this movie just has nothing going for it. Sure, the characters are likable, but the premise fails miserably. If there are going to be curses, there needs to be an explanation. I really doubt an old lady is going to curse someone just because of reposession. I would think there would be a lot bigger worries than that.

Scares are predictable at best. The problem is the story just doesn't meld well. There's no plot except for Christine trying to ward off a curse. If there was more explanation about how the curse works, much earlier, the plot may have been mildy enticing; without a scientific explanation, I feel lost watching this movie. The intro feels cheesy. Why is a woman being dragged to Hell? Why not somewhere else? Why don't they just disappear? If there's going to be supernatural causes, they need explanations. That's how I feel anyway.

I suppose the whole story could be much more interesting if the director had taken a "beautiful mind" approach. The entire movie, we could be aware of the illusions Christine is having.

I really didn't understand this movie. I don't get a kick out of watching excorcisms, demons, people being dragged to hell, and this most certainly isn't scary; at best, Drag me to Hell is laughable. There is nothing scary here.

1 out of 10 for a bad movie.

title: Forget the rating, this movie is very weak
review: I am crazy how this movie have this rating, sucks ... This movie is not a horror movie, is comedy, made by people with just half brain. I don t understand how this movie have 6,7 rating when it should be a 4, and i give that note because the special effects are good,in fact are the only thing good in this movie. If you are a fan of Evil Dead and that kind of movies i you maybe like this movie. But this movie is a authentic comedy without funny, it looks that was been written by a 10 years old child. This is just another stupid movie. I saw this movie because of the rating in this site and one more time i was tricked. Perhaps it is time to ignore the ratings and see the movies that i really want to see without care the opinion of the others.

title: Raimi's return to his Evil Dead roots
review:
DRAG ME TO HELL sees Sam Raimi attempting to update his EVIL DEAD formula to the modern era, reinventing it as a teen-friendly comic horror about an unsuspecting bank worker who becomes a victim of a witch's curse. It sounds entertaining, and you'd think it would be easy for a man who once made it his job to bring fresh, energetic horror to our cinema screens.

Sadly, time has passed, and nowadays the formula seems a little stale. Raimi relies far too much on CGI in this movie, so that most of the (frequent) scare scenes are fake-looking and cartoonish; sometimes making this look like a Looney Tunes cartoon done via live action. I'd much have preferred practical effects, because then the film wouldn't have been so cheesy and laughable.

The mood is all over the place, too. The witch's curse storyline has real potential to be interesting, but none of the scare scenes work, mainly because Raimi goes for the gross-out over the genuinely spooky. There's a kind of infantile relish in watching a toothless old crone slobbering over her victim that makes me wonder what exactly he was thinking of. Playing it straight would have worked far better, I think.

The cast is nothing to write home about, with performances ranging from the pantomime (Dileep Rao) to the decent (David Paymer). As the heroine, Alison Lohman tries very hard to convince, although she does fail to elicit much sympathy. The pacing's good, though, and there are plenty of set-pieces and jump-in-your-seat moments, so undemanding horror fans might find themselves entertained regardless. Sometimes, though, Raimi goes too far; take the goat scene: just what on earth was he thinking?

title: Hellish!
review: I'm not a huge fan of Sam Raimi, with the exception of the Spider-Man trilogy, I tend to stay away from his movies, but something "dragged" me to this movie. I probably just wanted something scary with a twisted sense of humour and an interesting premise. The premise was interesting - young woman refuses to help an old gypsy woman and gets cursed by said old woman. However, I got none of the scares or the laughs, what I got was a predictable and frustrating load of tosh that had every horror flick clich√© ever devised; the windows suddenly bursting open, the spectre behind the curtain, the cursed objects, the rituals etc, etc, the list goes on and on, even the ending is clich√©d and predictable. Just terrible.

title: I'm an easy grader who rarely trashes anything. But this is pure trash.
review:
I may have seen just one too many horror films, or one to few.

OK, the old lady started off as being real creepy, a very good feature that could have been played as the ace in the hole. Instead? She spent the entire film vomiting gore out of her mouth into others' mouths. How lovely, thanks for that! Now I'm not a gore fan, not one bit. And even if I were - this was the toilet humor level of gore. Plain filth with no art what so ever.

OK, story is nice, in its own predictable non original juvenile way. There have been enough films that dealt with curses and evil spirits, this has to be the worst I've seen. Even the so-called "moral" of the story is self righteous and condescending... cheap. Very cheap. Not karma, but self indulgence.

The only times you might find yourself frightened is when the oldest cheap shot cheat in the book is played - something happens quickly and suddenly and loud audio forces you to twitch. Like a 13 year old bringing a wild card to a Texas Hold'em table.

Now, the grand finale - the """twist""". So obvious, so predictable, so insultingly blunt... next time try putting a little more work to the story writing, Raimi bros, instead of blowing through 30 million dollars on corny Michael Bay effects. This wasn't supposed to be an action film with explosions and fire, it was supposed to be horror, as in scary, as in good.

I apologize, this review didn't come out objective. That's only because I will never get 99 minutes back, and am both frustrated and disappointed. I wouldn't mind a low level twist, I'd even prefer no twist at all than such a lame one. Maybe a 12 year old watching the first Horror film in their lives could have somehow missed that... And the ending doesn't even follow up on the twist! I mean COME ON!

I'm going to be as objective as I can and rate this film 3. If anyone asks me - I'll recommend watching 99 minutes of static white noise on a dead channel before going through the non-existing effort of hitting the play button on this one.

title: Well, can't you at least gently pull me in the general direction, then?
review: Unrated Director's Cut. Christine Brown(Lohman, trying her darndest to imbue the role with some measure of personality... to no avail, both leads are dull and forgettable) has a nice life. Her boyfriend is... uh, well, a Mac, I think(or at least, she has one... and he has a Smartphone. And the producers think you should, too). Actually, no, he is introduced unable to fix a printer, so I guess he's a doctor(...I love Justin Long, although I think he should stay away from this kind of work(he never seems to fare well in them...), but not sure I buy him as that). She's a loan officer, and she may get a promotion! Ah, but to beat out the just-hired(get it? It's a... joke... and no, they're pretty much all that uninspired) Stu(who I think is the Joxer of modern times... no, I don't know why they didn't just give the role to Ted) for the job, she may have to make a tough decision. Or she'll have to choose whether to grant a third extension on a mortgage payment. Of course the answer is no. Bounds of reason! Whazzat? We're supposed to think that's awful? Oh, we're reinforcing the old stereotype about bankers cheating people out of their money. I guess we should just be grateful she's not a hook-nosed Jew. Anyway, this means an elderly female Gypsy will be evicted, and she choose to curse our protagonist - no, with a demon, not with colorful language... after all, this is a PG-13 film. This is a pretty polarizing one... critics love it(it would appear that they anticipated Mr. Evil Dead's return to horror so much, they'll take anything), a lot of viewers hate it. Sam Raimi is clearly more invested in the copious amounts of bodily fluids(blood is only one of them...) than the characters(who are evidently mainly there so he has someone to throw into walls(though our hero shrugs that off surprisingly well...), get bile on and get embarrassed... and that's the comedy(hey, if you like it in his other efforts, I suppose you may, here, too)), and that's of course his call(as long as he accepts that if he gives us nothing substantial to chew on, we'll forget this soon after watching it... and that's precisely what happens). However, he tries to have his cake and eat it too by trying to capitalize on our sympathy for the them that could have been there. The ending is admittedly grim... and as a public service, they warn you ahead of time, by telegraphing it. FX are a genuine positive, the CGI looks real and is so well-integrated, you can't tell where one ends and the other begins. The major problem here is that the shocks are nearly all, with hardly any exceptions, jumpscares. Yes, an obvious ones, too. The sound gets really low, then, BAM! Something gets in your face, the volume gets cranked, and that is supposed to be terrifying, rather than merely obnoxious. This is 94 minutes long without credits. There is a lot of violence and disturbing content as well as a little moderate to strong language in this. I recommend this to fans of the recent string of unwanted remakes that have plagued this genre. 6/10

title: Seriously?
review:
This review contains spoiler, please do not read it before watching the movie.

Phew, I'm still looking for the best words to describe this movie but the only one that is coming to my mind is: RIDICULOUS. What's with this story, what's with these sometimes strange, sometimes disgusting but more importantly mostly pointless and actually really laughable happenings? Gypsy curses, mediums who are waiting for this opportunity all of their lives (they still want 10.000 bucks for fulfilling the dream of their lives), dead bodies vomiting green stuff, tons of hair pulled out without any visible change, goats talking, people obsessed, demons summoned, envelopes mixed up, flies going to the strangest places, one liter of blood spraying from noses and mouthes but the person walks away just fine, old-lady attack in a previously locked up car, graves turning into flooded swamps, evil handkerchiefs, and I could go on like this forever. The only acceptable feeling that this movie made me have is that I genuinely disliked this Christine girl.

Well, this movie was quite an experience with hysterical laughing attacks from my side and incredulous looks from my husband who believed I'm watching horror again (as a matter of fact, that was the original plan) and just couldn't understand my outbursts. If this movie were classified as comedy, my rating would be a 10/10. However, if you want a really surreal experience, give it a try.

title: it Will seriously drag you to hell..!!
review: i just saw this movie because it was having a rating of 6.8 and most of the horror movies are around this.. so i thought it would be a fun and scary ride.. but i was so wrong..!!! everything in this movie is pathetic.. acting of Christine brown, Rham Jas.. their dialogues.. story is also predictable.. and it was pain to watch.. it wasn't scary at all.. and the scenes that were meant to be scary were funny.. at one point they became pain to watch.. they were unbearable.. the monster that was the whole point of the story was only for just 5 minutes and was dancing.. cm on..!!! what were u thinking while making this movie.. how anyone can rate this movie more than 2.. i usually dnt write reviews bt i am writing this to warn you.. its nt scary at all.. even acting is not good.. the only gud thing about this movie was it ended.. nthng else..!! its nt even a good time pass movie.. if you are not wathcing it.. u arnt missing anythng.. though ur saving ur time and money..!!

title: Unimpressive.
review:
I decided to watch the film after hearing about the positive rating in RT. But this is one of the few times when I am disappointed with the ratings. The film follows a plot which is too normal. The disappointing thing for me was that it was handled with a little comedy. The film is for casual viewers and serious film lovers might not like it.

PROS: The only thing that was worth watching was the couple. The girl whenever with the boy was looking too cute. They might have made a hit Romantic film if I may suggest.

CONS: The most irritating thing that I find in a horror film is the frequent usage of sudden bursts of sound and too much showing of blood and nasty liquids. And this film is a mix of all that. To add more to this is the comic handling of the concept. I didn't even find the acting of the lead character to be impressive. Too much CGI also killed the pleasure in the film.

Message: "Do not mess with freaks."

Verdict: "Watch at your own risk."

title: Aside from a several "laugh out loud" cheesy moments, it was not "bad."
review: OK....The blood spurting nose was hysterical for its cartoonesque absurdity. "Did I get any in my mouth! Did I get any in my mouth! Did I get any in my mouth!" exclaims the bank's manager as a hose's worth of blood projects from Jill's right nostril. Too funny! Another really funny moment (and I did "lol") was when Mrs. Ganush "gums" Jill's chin; haha!! Too funny. And the projectile maggot vomit scene was also very humorous, as was the projectile cat vomit scene (no, it's not a cat vomiting, it's a character puking up a cat!). There are other moments too....arm in the mouth, up to the elbow!! OUCH! The phony goat! All very funny. But the funniest moment of the film for me was when -- AFTER THE HOSE-WORTHY BLOOD FROM THE RIGHT NOSTRIL SCENE IN THE BANK -- Justin Long's character says to Jill, "Hi. I heard you left work early today." YOU DID!!!!!!!! YOU HEARD SHE LEFT WORK EARLY!!!!???? Did they tell you that she actually re-painted the inside of the bank, including the PEOPLE, WITH BLOOD FROM HER RIGHT NOSTRIL!!!!!!!!??????????????? No. Oh. They must have forgotten. Anyway, I'm not utterly killing the film. Just know that there are some ridiculously amusing moments in a film that, every once in a while is a little creepy. Lower your standards. Tune your sense of humor, and enjoy it.

title: Makes a Silly Mockery of Everything
review:
This was just unpleasant to watch. Although it's meant as a 'joke' of some sort, it was a poorly executed piece of film. It's made of shoddily done scenes, adhered with what could have been a reasonable storyline. And this is was annoys me, that this film made a mockery of a plot which, had it been captured by actual filmmakers instead of bored people with too much time on their hands with an ulterior monetary motive, this film might have been a nice little story.

Unfortunately, it turned out as an unfortunate piece of rubbish deserving of very little.

I can see that it's trying to be satire, but it just isn't; it's not subtle, not explicit, and only carries an intention, not the execution. It's a sad, sad, piece of horror-comedy that accidentally got dropped in the dirt. Oops.

title: Drag Me to Hell
review:

2.Film's topic is very attractive.

3.Until the film is finished,ƒ±t is very exciting.

title: Unchilling Chiller
review:
Thought this one would have been worth getting out of the house, paying admission and going to see on the big screen.

Boy was I wrong. Thankfully all I spent on this piece was time.

The premise sounded solid: young upwardly mobile loan officer has a curse thrown on her after she refuses an extension on an old woman's mortgage payments.

Sounds like an opportunity for some really scary scenes, themes and creepy images that will stick with you long after the movie is over.

Wish that was true. Producers use the same bit three times during the movie, a bit that was not scary the first time, just gross to be gross.

Nothing integral to the plot or that heightens the tension or shocks and horrifies, just things that show up like fake vomit to disgust rather than as the result of the character's pursuit of of her objective: to get the curse thrown off.

Lots of little, cheap stunts like that, moments the viewer just knows someone sat up during a production meeting and said " How cool would this be if we did XXXXX ? Real gross out man. Those kids will be talking about it for years !"

Another element that works against the movie is that it is filmed and lit like a TV sitcom: too bright, too colorful, too sunny. There seems to be no attempt to create a mood of foreboding, an atmosphere of tension and fear.

Gross out scenes can never take the place of something creepy, and disturbing happening as if all around the viewer.

Cheap shocks can't take the place of a movie experience where the viewer can actually imagine themselves in the same situation.That is the province of actual film making and is created via lighting, music, plot line, pacing and camera angles.

For instance the medium Alison Lohman and Justin long visit,Dileep Rao looks,sounds and acts like a salesmen from the Men's Wearhouse suit chain rather than a charismatic envoy of the supernatural world.

Nice cast, potentially interesting plot,some nice moments, acting is believable in most cases and a genuinely worthwhile plot twist along the way make the movie passably entertaining, but certainly no classic.

Filmed in too bright and brittle a manner to be a truly scary horror film.The lighting alone destroys the possibility of ever making the viewer a participant in the heroine's terror or even to win sympathy for her.

The rest of it is just silly filler posing as scary movie elements. Disappointing. Would be a "horror classic" if one saw it at age 8.

title: 2 thumbs up
review: i rented drag me to hell from blockbuster video and it scared the crap out of me. i mean, i've loved horror flicks since i was a teenager and now i am 51 and i give this movie 2 thumbs up. i love a good horror flick that can keep you spellbound and keep you guessing till the end. i was totally shocked by the ending and wasn't expecting what had happened. great job sam raimis. i would recommend this movie to anybody that likes horror. i'm like, this is just as good as any movie that was based on any book done by stephen king or clive barker or any master of horror. at first i was skeptical about watching it, thinking that it wouldn't be any good, but it was great from beginning to end. sure it started off a little slow in my opinion, but most movies start off that way but then they get into the real action

title: Horror(!) film review
review: From the starting, i felt that i would love this film because the starting scene and the soundtrack of that scene were really impressive. But as it continued, i did not think in that way. The reason was i do not like horror films. But this film did not make me fear.Contrarily, i laughed at some scenes. Still, the choice of the cast were really successful. The woman who cursed the young woman was the exact person that should be in this film for example. Although some effects of the film were really successful, the goat icon,the handkerchief and even the wizard's beards, the film generally contained bad scenes that could make you feel queasy. While watching i was about to vomit in some parts. During the film i was the girl's side but i liked the end of the film mostly. Generally i like the bad-ending films and other things. Especially for this film, it shot me in the end.

And when we watching this scene we were angry also we feel unhappy because the girl did everything that she can do but she could not be successful, she died. However, after all these events if the film ended with happiness this could be absurd. How I felt sad I love only end of the film.

title: It was so nice.
review: I can say this sentence about this film, it was so nice. And I think that it was a real horror film. Even though I don't watch horror films so much, I didn't leave it and I watched it till the end. This film has original scenes. Apart from this, the excellent special effects were in the scenes and these made the film special and nice. The story of the film is about the mythology. But, after a while, she thinks that her boss will not give this chance to her. At the same time, she competes with one worker for this position. But she starts to hallucinate. Then she meets a psychologist. She goes on therapy for some time. And then she notice that she must protect herself. Shortly, the story of the film is so. And I say again that I like the film . And if you ask me, you must certainly watch this film. Be sure, you like it and you will not regret for watching it ! ...

title: one of my favourite scary movie
review: first of all, the movie is great. Justin Long plays his role lively.in the movie, he is funny and cute and loves his girlfriend sincerely. On the other hand, Alison Lohman's bleeding nose part is awesome. In the film there are a few scary parts loved by almost everyone who watched the movie. for instance; while Cristine is in her car, in the seat back Slvia Ganush's ugly,disturbing,annoying face comes directly to the rearview mirror or Sylvia Ganush's teethless mouth comes directly to Christien's chin. title: comment
review: I watched this movie at the listening and pronunciation lesson. When I watched the beginning of the film I disappointed .There is not any interesting things . The story is about the mythology. It is just a mention with an obvious wink and grin following. It is about Christine Brown is a loans officer at a bank. She is worried about a lot of in life. She is in competition for an assistant manager position .She is worried that her boss will think less of her if she shows weakness, she refuses a time extension on a loan to an old woman, Mrs. Ganush, she now faces foreclosure and the loss of her house. Christine Brown is attacked by Mrs. Ganush after she doesn't accept to offer a loan. When she starts to hallucinate; confides in boyfriend, Clay. He is a Professional Psychologist. The steps she has to undertake to protect herself. Even though it'd be an interesting turn to make, and a slightly strange one at that, all of this is just rumor. Now I understand the ending, I just find myself still disappointed that this lovely innocent girl is punished by this horrible woman , if one asks me about this movie, I don't strongly advise it

title: comments
review: I thought Christine Brown was great. She fought back and really wrestled with her options. I would love to see a sequel, but I am not sure how they would do it. Hell is not really Hell if there is possibility of escape, so a Justin Long tries to get her back sequel would be pretty grim. If she was really good, she would not have fallen victim in the first place. I thought the Hume was a little much. I prefer scary to funny or disgusting, but when it comes to horror movies where there is more to fear than just death, this is the only decent one I can think of. Raimi is in to sequels so that might be possible. Howsoever, he tends more towards the Lovecraft viewpoint than the biblical (while using his own mythologies) . I.e. there are gods and demons but none of them are nice. In Lovecraft, the only reason nice places like we know can even exist is because the universe is in a temporary state where the bad things are dead ‚Äî but they will eventually revive. Meanwhile their servants are bad enough. Course, maybe Justin Long can get Tim Allen and the crew of the USS Protector to come help. They owe him one. Since Sigourney Weaver is in that lineup, the Lima would be in deep serious trouble.

title: Drag Me to Hell
review: I watched this movie in ELT department for to exercise about pronunciation. He chose Drug Me To Hell which is one of 2009 American horror films. It was scary but just because it was really jumpy. It was a very predictable movie and the talking goat just made it. I have never laughed so hard at any horror film in my life. It was combined comedy film and horror film. There is a woman who she's a young, eager loan officer working in a Los Angeles bank and she wants to be an Assistant Manager. Her boss though seems to prefer another colleague less talented than her. Then she denies an old gypsy woman who gives an extension on her mortgage causing her to lose her house. And the old woman puts a curse on the officer. She will be tortured by evil spirit by three days and then dragged into hell. The young woman tries to get out of the curse. There are also unexpected moments that I was shocked. I should say the end of movie was great. I think that this movie should give 8.0 points. Because this is difference movie which combines two different kind of movie.

title: To all users, watch it over !
review: First time I saw it, I totally agreed with most of you! Almost the worst "scary" (because it wasn't scary, it was just disgusting!) film I've ever seen. Then a friend told me " I heard about that film, it talks about eating disorders right?" I first thought he was crazy or just confused when I asked the why's he told me "all the parts in which the old lady appears are related to food or most take place in the kitchen" So, I had to watch it again, it wasn't even 10 minutes when I realized it was true! First in the bakery store, then at work she is always drinking only coffee, then with the picture she watches in the kitchen of her when she was an over-weighted child it could be more clear! Maybe for some of you, it wont matter at all, it is still a bad scary movie, but that was the entire message of it. These kind of disorders ain't pretty and can take you to death. So of you'd like to have a new perspective on this film watch it over.

title: No "Evil Dead"
review: The first time I saw this, I thought I was watching a Wes Craven film, and that's not meant as a compliment. Craven hasn't made a decent film in 20 years. Imagine my shock and horror when I finally discovered this is a Sam Raimi film. Obviously, Raimi is off his game by a wide margin here. A loan officer played by Alison Lohman ends up under a curse placed on her by an old crone, and the rest of the film details the spirit of the now-deceased crone haunting the young banker. Most of the scares come from loud noises, musical cues and scary faces. If such things are enough to scare you, you will probably enjoy this. Personally, I think Raimi intended it to be a comedy, as witnessed by the incredibly loopy seance, which by the way is right out of Raimi's "Evil Dead." I like Alison Lohman; she's sort of the clean-cut version of Lindsay Lohan. And I like Justin Long, if for no other reason than he is from my home state and grew up near me. Also, he did a bang-up job years ago in "Jeepers Creepers" (he was sadly missed in the sequel) and "Galaxy Quest." The two actors play well together, but they can't save this uneven mess. Watch it at your peril.

title: gross and pointless
review: I've just watched it with my bf, who loved it, but for me, the whole thing seemed just a pointless profanity. The characters seem to throw up every time and, and these body juices of all color and consistency, along with some scary and really just gross appearances would guarantee the "horror" part of the movie. Well, at least for some people. For me,it was just disappointing from the beginning to the end. Meaningless story with zero credibility, and Scarrymovie-like scenes, flat and just disgusting. I would not recommend it for anyone fascinated to the fans of psychological or mystery horror. In fact, I don't recommend it to anyone. Waste of time in my opinion

title: A disappointment
review: I have only just got to watch this movie and seeing that it had a score of 7 I though that it would be a good movie. Well I can say that I was very disappointed. I am glad that I watched it on TV and didn't pay any money to rent it out. I have read in some other reviews of this title that "Raimi" is a maker of Great Titles. Well I can only say that he has failed this time. The movie had a good story line with pleasant scenery and a good music score, the actors where good and played their parts in a convincing manner. The scary bits where "in-your-face" good and did indeed scare me a bit, if I was in my teens again watching this film I would have been really scared. The special effects on the other hand were awful and unbelievable, really I don't know how Raimi could even think that they would scare a majority of the Adult movie viewers, no wonder it got a PG-13 rating as I feel that is who this movie is really targeted for. This Movie will not make into my movie collection solely on the huge let-down of it special effects.

title: Sorry Sam..
review:
This movie was promising, great combination, Sam Raimi, Justing Long and a horror Movie, everything pointed out to be great, I was wrong.

There are probably 2 good things in this movie 20 minutes with Justin Long that in the end you just feel that his talent is wasted in the movie and probably the best thing the Old Lady the she probably makes me give this movie a 5 and not a 3. Other than that everything is terrible, the acting is bad, the plot could have done much much more with the supernatural elements, the camera work could have been wonderful but his vision really did not work for this movie, everything just turns out being bland and predictable with no suspense build up or anything.

90% of this movie is during the day! I have said this before What is with this new trend, seriously if you have a bad horror script/movie/director just make it during the night it will at least give you half a point more.

I tried to give this movie a chance thinking it will get better, at some point I thought about this being an homage to old horror movie or even a B movie after 20 minutes in.... nothing worked.

Sorry Sam...

title: A well crafted horror flick from Sam Raimi
review:
"Drag Me to Hell" was Sam Raimi's long-awaited return to the genre that gave him his earliest successes with the "Evil Dead" movies. However, this time, with the blockbuster status of the Spider-Man films behind him, he wasn't constricted by a low budget.

That's not to say that "Drag Me to Hell" is a glossy horror picture lacking in visceral impact. The film looks nice (thanks in no small part to Raimi's talents behind the camera) but it also delivers thrills to spare.

The script has a touch of hokey dialogue but overall it presents a compelling story that doesn't just recycle the usual horror tropes. There are a number of gross-out moments but the PG-13 rating attests to Raimi's decision not to rely on gore for the film's impact. Instead, Raimi masterfully manipulates the audience's emotions with suspenseful storytelling techniques.

All of this being said, I feel that the acting isn't up to the same standard as the rest of the movie. The star, Alison Lohman, just isn't very interesting in my eyes. Justin Long fares a little better while Dileep Rao contributes what is easily the film's most memorable performance. The supporting players are all satisfactory but there's little here that stands out in terms of acting.

Ultimately, "Drag Me to Hell" delivers the goods as far as a horror movie is concerned. I'd even say that it's well worth the time for those who normally don't care much for horror movies. In my opinion, the flick's visual panache and genuine chills place it a few notches above typical modern horror fare.

title: Disappointing!
review:
I haven't exactly seen many horror films and I was pleased when I got the chance to watch one. However this film left me unexpectedly laughing throughout rather than jumping out of my skin. I'm not too sure if Sam Raimi was trying to make a horror film or he was actually mocking the genre. As a slight newcomer to this genre I wasn't sure if an attacking handkerchief, a cartoon like talking goat and a dancing demon was meant to be thrilling? The film's plot was rather simple and the basis of it could have possibly made for a good horror film. A loan officer, Christine Brown, (Alison Lohman) has a curse placed on her coat button, after she refuses to extend a loan to an evil old gypsy lady. Subsequently she is frequently tormented by evil spirit demons from hell. She seeks help from an Indian fortune teller to rid her of the curse, but fails. After believing she has finally got rid of the button and curse she and the audience are 'shocked' to find out she hasn't. It was all very predictable and the writing was very lazy as there were many flaws in the storyline, the grave digging scene was particularly hard to believe.

Although the film did scrape out some good qualities, as there were some scenes that did make me jump, this was due to the way the director used the technique of suspense building. Throughout the film I noticed that whenever the sound/music stopped, there was going to be something that would jump out at you. Also there were times that made you believe there was a scary moment about to happen and something harmless would pop out, giving the audience a false sense of security. All in all I was rather disappointed with 'Drag Me to Hell' and I look forward to watching another horror film that hopefully doesn't make me laugh as much.

title: A Morality Tale?
review: My understanding is that the writers, Sam and Ivan Raimi, wanted to write a morality tale about how a good person makes a bad choice based upon greed and is punished for it. A good premise to make a movie on, but that was not in this movie. The bad decision was how the protagonist, Christine Brown, denied an old woman, Sylvia Ganush, a third extension on a mortgage payment so that Christine could get a promotion. Now I'm not familiar with all of the workings with a bank, but not giving a third extension doesn't sound like a bad move even if she did do it with the hopes of a promotion. So Ganush curses Christine and damns her to hell. When Christine goes to confront Ganush, it is revealed that Ganush died. This makes Christine's decision moot because Ganush did not die as a result of the decision. This is more of an immorality tale; if someone doesn't give you what you want, inflict immense pain and suffering upon them.

title: Horror/comedy/60'es
review:
When thinking about what to write in this review, the first thing that came to mind, was the image of a 60'es horror movie i ones saw. The music, the filming the acting - everything reminds me of how i remember this old movie.

The effects in Drag me to hell was all right. Nothing extraordinary. The acting - not good. The directing - under average i would say.

I really don't think, this movie should be mentioned as a horror or thriller genre. I would rather denote it as something of a mutation between comedy and mystery. Perhaps some horror, but you really have to be half a nervous wreck, if the few horror elements the movie offers, will scare you anything above a "booh".

title: Neither serious nor hilarious, neither excellent nor awful.
review:
The trailers for this film did a good job in building it up to be a legitimate entry amongst the best horror efforts of the 00's. Even the DVD sleeve alone raised my expectations, and I almost found myself believing the perhaps over-zealous tag-line courtesy of Zoo; "the scariest movie of the decade". Unfortunately though, the writer of the aforementioned magazine's review, Charlie Parrish, apparently was either trying to pull a fast one on us, or has a critically low fear threshold.

I'm not going to say that it was terrible; it wasn't. There were plenty of well-executed shocks and I was kept watching until the end. It had the ingredients for a good horror film. Perhaps they just weren't mixed together in the right amounts.

My main problem was the attempt at genre definition. The trailers, the adverts, all the publicity, built it up to be purely horror; scares and jumps galore. However, the comedic aspects when watching the film itself led me to believe that perhaps it should have been described as a comedy-horror, or even just made its mind up from the two. In fact, it's so laden with clich√©s that, if it had been intended as such, it would have gained a higher rating from me. I simply didn't know whether or not to take it seriously.

Some of the shocks took me by surprise; good horror in that respect. Some of the gruesome bodily-fluid-related surprises made me laugh; good comedy in that respect. The balance just wasn't right, though. I don't agree with the one-star reviews that label the film as boring, dry, terrible... there are definitely traces of good film in there. I certainly don't agree with the ten-star reviews however, labelling it as a return to "classic horror", unless your idea of "classic horror" is mediocre acting and downright daft portrayals of possession (i.e. a man experiencing catatonia during a s√©ance, which looks more like some sort of bizarre dad-at-a-wedding type of dance).

If you begin to watch this expecting a frightening watching experience, you'll be disappointed, probably. If you watch it expecting to draw some laughs out of it, you'll probably enjoy it more.

title: a very annoying movie
review:
the storyline was illogical and childish; the actors were not fit for the parts; and there were many boring segments.

it's hard to understand how this could ever be considered a horror film considering i spent a lot of the time gagging in my mouth at how idiotic it was. i still don't understand how i made it through the entire movie.

the only thing that made the movie worthwhile was seeing the main character get sucked into hell at the very end. by that time i had built up such a hatred for her character that it was a relief to see her go. i only wish her boyfriend could have received the same fate -- in the movie, and as pertains to his acting career.

this movie is NOT worth anyone's time.

title: Stay far away from this one..
review:
My first review on IMDb, and for good reason - I felt compelled to warn other viewers about this title and the time they'd be wasting if they decided to watch it. I felt a 3/10 was generous, for several reasons.

The use of old and cheap cues to elicit startled responses from the viewer is completely overdone in this movie. Loud and obnoxious sounds, flashing of scary single-frames in your face, etc.. all really begin to grate after a while and numb the viewer to the rest of the movie.

Additionally, while certain films (the Evil Dead series) either really ARE scary, or treat themselves with a good dose of humor while still being so.. this one can't seem to make its mind up. It never really commits to being truly scary, or truly funny, or even a combo of both. It is in a sort of limbo and really leaves you more confused and feeling like someone tried to pull a cheap scare off on you, again and again.

I'm not going to spoil the plot in any way - I personally didn't even finish watching my first viewing of the movie, it was that bad. I was rolling my eyes ten minutes in, and sighing loudly at twenty. Too many horribly predictable plot twists, scare mechanisms, and just bad writing really ruin the experience.

If you have nothing but time to waste, then perhaps you can burn it on a single seating with Drag Me to Hell. If you value your personal time and your quality of life, take the better option - watch something with an interesting plot instead.

title: Horror or Comedy?
review: I may have a bad opinion of this movie because I approached it as a genuine horror, admittedly different people find different things scary but labelling this title as 'the scariest movie of the decade' (Charlie Parrish, Zoo) is misleading and a terrible overstatement. If I were Alison Lohman, I'd be embarrassed to hold my name to it. Had Drag Me To Hell been marketed as a classic horror comedy maybe moments throughout could be laughed at, rather than cringed...Although the first thirty minutes are entertaining, the only vague noticeable influence from director Sam Raimi despite the cheesy gore reminiscent of the Evil Dead trilogy. Though this may be a pitiful excuse for a horror movie, as a comedy it is entertaining watch, but don't expect any kills and thrills, just a few jumps and some fake gore.

title: Drag me to horror movie-heaven.
review:
Rating: ***1/2 out of 4.

Critics, audiences, and horror movie buffs are already torn between the consensus of Sam Raimi's return-to-horror-roots effort DRAG ME TO HELL; some critics declared it an instant cult classic while others, some horror movie buffs included, were skeptical. Me, I just thought DRAG ME TO HELL was the most fun I ever had in a horror movie in a long time. Is it a new classic? Only time will tell, but saying DRAG ME TO HELL is more fun than a bucket-load (or maybe even a shipload) of PG-13 horror remakes would be a dead give-away.

At first, I too was very skeptical as to what makes Raimi's latest horror offering worth of high-praise. This not the first time since his EVIL DEAD trilogy that he touched a horror movie since he served as a producer to some crappy PG-13 horror remakes like THE MESSENGERS and THE GRUDGE 2; that's not really a good sign. But this is his first since in the genre both as a director and writer (along with brother Ivan), and finally mys distinctions of Raimi as a bit rusty has been proved wrong. In fact, seeing DRAG ME TO HELL kind of improved my affection for Raimi himself. I liked his earlier SPIDER-MAN pictures, but didn't hold any particularly high affection to them. Now that I've seen DRAG ME TO HELL (after missing out on it in the big-screen), I may have a higher appreciation for Raimi's style in his preferred genre and the manic energy in his earlier films. The EVIL DEAD series were gory, violent, but at the same time twisted funny and maniacally entertaining. DMTH throws us back to that era where Raimi's infant terrible sensibilities are at a high point.

Alison Lohmann plays Christine Brown, a loan officer who longs for the position of an assistant manager position. She gives it her all, but her play-nice sensibilities puts him behind his scheming, butt-kissing competition Stu Rubin (Reggie Lee). It doesn't help when her unlikely position doesn't make an impression on the parents of her boyfriend Clay (Justin Long). Christine gets her chance to prove herself a tough decision maker when a old lady named Mrs. Ganush (Lorna Raver) begs for an extension to her loan. Christine makes the decision to decline, making a good impression to her boss Jim Jacks (David Paymer, in an amusing straight-faced performance). But something's not right with the old Ganush crone, and after assaulting her in her car, Christine is cursed by the old woman to be sent to hell by demons within a few days.

Like his earlier works, DRAG ME TO HELL pushes every jump scare and gross-out horror to over-the-top heights, serving it up with shock and equal amounts of sadistic humor, but playing it all with a straight-face (Don't worry about laughing during the scenes meant to be scary or solemn, Raimi and co. are laughing along with you). Like The Looney Tunes before him and Peter Jackson and Robert Rodriguez after, Raimi orchestrates his slapstick horror mayhem like a shameless prankster that he is, and there's also I kind of randomness to them; even at its most solemn, Raimi playfully throws in a scare or to unexpectedly. The special effects themselves look relatively low-tech but insanely playful, like the crazy Deadites of his earlier projects. Christopher Young's Elfman-esque score is loud and over-caffeinated, clearly playing those infamous jump-scare tactics of horror movies for laughs. The film may be PG-13, but pushes the envelope to the extremes with it; this is definitely the most fun PG-13 horror movie to date! Think Tourneur's NIGHT OF THE DEMON and THE EXORCIST played out as a Three-Stooges comedy and you got a clear picture of DRAG ME TO HELL.

Lohmann is fun to watch (especially when she goes all tough when the spirits pushed her around too far), and a great sport considering the amount of disgusting, twisted hijinks she had to endure. Justin Long is hilarious playing what seems to be a needless role as the boyfriend, always standing around and "believing in her", but doing very little to actually save her. Dileep Rao is even funnier in a straight-faced performance as the psychic determined to help Christine, but is either useless at providing procedures or conveniently giving them when it's almost too late. Adriana Barraza pops up near the end as the medium hell-bent (pardon the pun) to bring down the demon which she faced before many years ago. And then there's the goat...

Not everyone will succumb to Raimi's stomach-turning craziness and the film is already getting some heavy backlash. but go ahead and just go see DRAG ME TO HELL for yourself. If you, like me, thought the movie is just the usual serving of perfunctory PG-13 horror, you might be surprised after a second look on DVD, and maybe bring a few friends over to have someone jump off your seats and laugh along with you.

title: well done for what it is
review:
I am not, as a general rule, a horror movie person, and I decided to watch this one only because I'm a big fan of Raimi's Army of Darkness. But of course, that was a comedy in a horror-movie context, which is something quite different.

Drag Me to Hell falls somewhere between Army of Darkness and The Evil Dead, a movie I did not like at all (I can't remember what I thought of Evil Dead 2, but my vague recollection would be DMTH is closer to that).

The movie is a fairly standard horror movie story with some solid scares and some of the comical yet still creepy horror scenes Raimi is known for. It's not my type of movie, as I say, but it is entertaining.

However, the ending is incredibly lame. You know, if you've ever seen a horror movie before in your life, that the ending is coming near a half hour before it arrives, and because it's a stupid, predictable, unoriginal ending, it is extra frustrating to not only have to sit through it but to also have to sit through so much time expecting it. I realize this movie wasn't aiming for an original story, and was content to just deliver cheap scares and comedic horror, but I still just dislike it.

But then, I'm not a horror movie person.

title: Not even worth watching on a rainy day
review:
Everything from the opening excerpt, the opening credits, to the first "scary" scene, and to each and every additional second of the film was just full of cheesy, primitive, tasteless scenes. The story was just awful. Everything was forced. No character acted true to human behavior. The script obviously had sub-par writers with no sense of originality or sensibility. The acting was okay, but that's about it. The music was cheesy, the sound effects were cheesy, the scary parts weren't scary.

I can understand that people who don't normally watch horror movies for pleasure might get scared or tinkle in their pants a little, but this was just pathetic. Don't even bother watching this.

title: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Woman Scorned
review: After being rejected for a loan, an old gypsy woman puts a curse on the loan officer, making her life miserable. This horror film creates a very eerie atmosphere, with mysterious forces in action in the dark. However, it's more comical than scary and that may be by design. It seems Raimi is having fun with this and not taking any of it too seriously. Some scenes involving slimy critters and bodily fluids go too far however. Lohman does fine as the loan officer who picks the wrong customer to tick off. Long plays her boyfriend and it's hard to see him as anyone other than the Mac guy. It's all quite silly but one could do worse.

title: pathetic n awful
review: "drag me to hell.!!"this was the only word which I was able to say after watching this horror flick.!! if this is what we call horror then sorry guys I am very much comfortable with the other genres. Most of the scenes make one laugh instead of giving goose bumps.Its spooky in some sense but talking of a complete horror package, it fails. Pathetic and awful are the only adjectives I can use right now.The movie starts slowly but as we move forward it revs itself up.But again disappointment... it only gains speed in its running way.Talking of acting, there is not a single performance in the movie to take your hats off.I was forced by my roommate to watch the movie, but after watching this i would also like to drag him to hell.

title: Either you hate it or love it. (or really liked it like i did)
review:
Okay i saw this movie when it came out in theaters and i liked it. It was a true refreshment cause all the other movies coming out where freaking haunting in Connecticut (blah) obsessed (ewwwww)the uninvited (okay) the unborn(disappointing)etc. not a lot of horror movies around the best of the bunch was this one

but i saw it again, and posted on facebook how much i really liked it and said it was a great horror movie for a pg 13 movie, and people start saying how much it sucked

the effects sucked ass, the ending was stupid, the whole movie wasn't scary, but just gross, i expected more.

my defense to it was: the effects were pretty bad, but the atmosphere was put there very well, the boo scares where a little more than boo scares, the demon actually did something to the main character than boo scare her and disappear (Cough nightmare on elm street 2010 cough) the demon slapped her face around, threw her everywhere, tormented her with freaky images and sounds, gave her nightmares and hallucinations to hype her paranoia.

then i went to this website and saw how many people hated it, and i read a bunch of them, and now, i'm not really sure what to say about it

are they people who expected hardcore horror from a pg 13 horror flick? where they disappointed because Bruce Campbell wasn't there? or is the movie really freaking bad!

so after reading the opinions of others, i'm with a question in my head. what makes a horror movie good or bad? i thought the acting was decent, there actually was some character development, things happened for a reason, every decision has a point (except a few minor exceptions)some things where over the top, some where actually creepy, and though it was long, it had enough things going on to entertain me.

so, after this long, review/ self thought on how i should rate this i

give it a 8 out of 10 it's freaking good

title: A lot of bang for your buck
review:
You get a lot of horror for 1 movie. There is everything from shock tactics to evil spirits. A little black comedy runs throughout.

Alison Lohman does a good job - looks a little too calm after each "encounter" - but she deserves her paycheck for the gross stuff she had to go through.

The topical story is amusing foreclosure. The old woman is good and gross. Justin Long is quite good too.

Enjoyed this more than the recent horror remakes like Friday 13th etc. because the story is more central to the movie instead of just incidental to the horror. Liked the ending.

Two thumbs up.

title: Drag Me to Hell and Don't Show Me This
review:
If there was an Academy Award for "Worst movie with a plot that could be resolved in thirty minutes or less", Drag Me to Hell would take the cake and eat it all. Sam Raimi returns after his successful "Spider Man" franchise and returns to the "Evil Dead" nostalgia he left us off with in 1987 bring us "Drag Me to Hell".

Let me first note this is not a Horror movie, hardly a suspense movie. Lets just call it a "Wanna be movie".

The plot revolves around Christine Brown (Allison Lohman) lives a normal life in present day Los Angeles working as a bank loan officer. After losing a promotion to her co-worker Stu (Reggie Lee), her boss tells her to become more strict of a loan officer and try to be more assertive and in control.

One day, an elderly gypsy woman by the name of Sylvia Ganush (Lorna Raver) walks up to Christine and asks her for a third extension on her overdue mortgage payment. Christine denies her the mortgage to seem more assertive and to prove to Mr. Jacks she has what it takes for the promotion, apologizing to her and saying there is nothing she can do. Ganush becomes angry at her and attacks Christine. She is taken out by guards a few moments later.

Fretting the issue, Christine gets into her car at the end of the day and is attacked by Ganush (which is very similar to the attack sequence in P2) who then puts a curse on her that she will be sentenced to Hell in three days.

After confronting her boyfriend (Justin Long), she then seeks help Rham Jas (Dileep Rao), a fortune teller who tells Christine she will be going to Hell in a matter of three days. He convinces her to make an animal sacrifice, to which then she kills her cat.

I shall admit this is the first movie I have walked out on in seven years (The Master of Disguise in 2002). It was not scary, a waste of my time, and after she killed the cat, I knew I was done.

I have never been a fan of Raimi's films, I will have to admit I never liked them. After seeing this, I'm guessing Raimi's "Spider Man 4" will be a little darker with satire seeing as in this film it's one of the darkest things he has done.

I should also mention this movie experiments a lot with effects. It uses including green screen, puppets, prosthetics and computer-generated imagery throughout. That's probably the only highlight since this movie wasn't at all scary.

The scene were she kills her cat was completely unnecessary, I found it saddening and just a ruin to what could have been a "decent" (and I use that term lightly) movie. Especially seeing as the Horror in this movie is very limited. The awkward silence scenes are screaming JUMP SCENE at you hoping you will jump. This movie tries to be something it will never be, scary.

Starring: Allison Lohman, Justin Long, Lorna Raver, and Dileep Rao. Directed by Sam Raimi.

title: I Got Drug to Hell !!!
review:
The is the worst movie I can ever remember seeing. It's as bad a movie that could probably be made if the whole idea was to see how bad a movie you could possibly make.

A total waste of almost two hours of my life. My real question is how could the Producers make a dime off this movie from hell, when the rating is PG13? I just can not imagine anyone over the age of 13 spending a dime to see this pile of sheep's dip,so how could anyone ever want to finance a movie that could (and this is probably being unfair to the children) only appeal to children under the age of 13 and not make back half of the production costs. I apologize to all the kids with a true taste of the good Cinema... not just the popcorn.

I have to say in closing the only reason I saw this pile was because I fell a sleep on a Saturday afternoon and woke up with this thing playing. It was like a car wreck is some people and I guess for me this day...It was so, so very ugly and bad, I couldn't turn away. So do yourself a favor and make sure you know what's coming on the TV when you take a nap you could wake up saying "Drag Me to Hell".

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1127180/usercomments-enter

title: Awful
review: This is the most horrible movie i've ever watched, I can't believe I stood calm long enough to watch the entire movie. This is a complete waste of time... I want my 2 hours back. I can't believe my eyes didn't start bleeding after this movie. If i'd had the possibility of rating this movie it would be -9. It doesn't have any logic, the storyline is predictable... it's just wrong ! It's the perfect torture for people. The characters are idiots ! The goat thing i mean.. what the... I you were a demon would you possess a goat ?! I mean how stupid can you be ?! The part where the old hag tries to bite the woman in the car without teeth does that seems like horror to you ?! Like I said, i can't believe i didn't throw the computer out the window. DO NOT WATCH !

title: when you see an anvil its all downhill from there
review:
to start off what the f@#$? This was a bad movie from the start. Everything from the crazy old lady to the accepting boyfriend absolutely sucked. the only refreshing character was the palm reader who had a sweet beard. what the hell is going on with everything going straight to this girls mouth? the f@#$ing old lady started gumming the $hit out of her face and her eyes popped out and went right for the mouth. i am so flabbergasted. seriously speechless. but to continue with my spiel, this movie is down right awful. and why is Justin long so stupid in this movie? i was watching this movie with my friends and if he didn't know any better he probably would have thought i was the director and i would have been embarrassed! i felt sorry for the that kitty. this movie lost all credibility when the girl went into the shed like thing looking for things to sell, when she moves the jacket or whatever the hell that was the supposed dead old lady jumps out of f@#$ing nowhere and attacks her. But what was really amazing about this scene was that she had a perfectly placed anvil tied to rope above the old lady oh and she just so happened to cut the rope in one swing while she was deep throating an entire arm. oh and again what the f@## is up with everything going into her mouth? IM GONNA GET SOME! awful actor awful movie awful script what else? this movie got worse when the old lady died i was actually getting excited for a good movie, boy was i wrong! the only thing i could attempt to call creepy was all the f@#$ing faces popping up out of nowhere! lastly the most ridiculous scene was when they were sitting around the table and the spirit enters the lady, enters the goat, oh and now goats can talk. but what i really laughed my a$$ off about was when the mustache f@#$er started dancing like he was Irish or some $hit. the end.

PS. whats with trying to develop a side story about the girl's struggling weight problem as a child. oh and my favorite part was when she figured out her boyfriend had the button and off to hell for her.

title: Army of Darkness for the kids taking our place
review:
I watched this movie and I was at first unimpressed. I thought "they have so much potential to make this a real horror"... then it hit me. This is just too damn funny to be a horror.

This reminded me of one of my favorite movies ¬Ö Army of Darkness. If you love Army of Darkness you will appreciate this movie.

The slapstick comedy is just hilarious. Having the devil or "Lamia" doing a jig during a s√©ance, old gypsy lady, after losing her teeth, gnawing on the heroine's bottom jaw, and my favorite is when the old hag vanishes under the car the heroine smears her head across the window looking for her.

Yes i did compare Army of Darkness with Drag me to Hell. Watch it and I Guarantee you will laugh.

title: Gripping and fast-paced - An excellent movie!
review:
Alison Lohman plays Christine Brown, a loan officer who is eager to be promoted to the position of assistant manager at her bank. To impress her boss, she refuses to grant an old gypsy woman an extension on her loan - therefore evicting the woman from her home. The woman, named Mrs. Ganush, avenges herself by cursing Christine. Christine now has three days to appease the dark spirit Mrs. Ganush unleashed or she will forever burn in hell. In doing this, she receives help from a fortune teller (played by Dileep Rao) and from her somewhat skeptical boyfriend (actor: Justin Long)...

All in all, the movie certainly lives up to its expectations: The movie contains many frightening scenes (not necessarily bloody, however) skillfully placed at the right moments in the storyline. The movie never drags a plot element out for too long so that the viewer gets bored.

Furthermore, the two main actresses (Alison Lohman and Lorna Raver as the gypsy woman) deliver great performances. The same also goes for Dileep Rao.

Rating: 8/10 stars

title: Ending ruins a good film yet again
review: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie; great acting, high gory factor, story (although premise had been done to death) great, up until the end; which I'm sorry but how could everyone involved in this film not realize one major thing in their attempt to make a surprising twist ending: the evil goat thing was supposed to get her BEFORE DAWN. Seriously that fact is mentioned I don't know how many times leading up to the ending yet it comes the next day. I mean I hate when endings don't add up with the rest of the movie. This really was going to be one of my favorite horror films, funny moments are always appreciated, but I prefer to laugh at comedy not a ridiculous ending. Not that I don't enjoy horror with evil endings, usually those are the best for me lol. It would just have made much more sense if it came for her the night it was supposed to. Other than that major flaw, I did enjoy it up until it stopped making sense. Lohman is great in everything she does so no surprise there. I really appreciated how her sexiness wasn't exploited at all in the film, no overexposure of cleavage or ditsiness; basically not a campy film. It was also refreshing to see Justin Long in another horror film, much more mature now and he was great too. Scary, shocking, funny, a film that had such great potential but ruined by the ending. Still worth checking out though if you enjoy gore.

title: A quality horror after many years
review:
I took the movie without much expectation. The movie turned out to be better than any horror movie have ever seen.

The movie is unlike any low budget horror flicks focusing more on gore and usual scare clich√©s. The movie has strong story-line and it develops as the movie proceeds. The concept of curse of Lamia is wicked and clearly explained, rather than just showing some bizarre phenomenon.

The movie is technically sound, well edited and proceeds with a fast pace. The acting natural and flawless. Mrs. Ganush is scary and convincing. The samll but important role by Dileep Rao is quite impressive and leaves convincing expression. Overall the movie is a rare find in horror category.

title: Weird but Surprisely Good.
review: I watched this movie at home with my older sister and my father. When I saw the trailer, I knew I wanted to watch this movie, because it looked and seemed very interesting. I was ready to get scared. But it turned out to be weird, funny, and a little scary. The one scary part was when (I believe the devil or a demon. I'm not sure what it was.) was after her she locked her self in her room and you could see the shadow of it under the door. The scenes with the old lady were nasty but funny. The movie still kept me hooked. The best part of the movie was the ending. Really loved it! I would watch this again. Great movie! It was really good and weird at sometimes.^^ 8/10

title: campy, gruesome, frenetic and most of all supremely entertaining
review: "Drag Me To Hell" finds director Sam Raimi coming back to his own roots. The movie is reminiscent of his cult Evil Dead series. Although it is not as amazing as "Evil Dead II", it still delivers a well-balanced combination of horror and comedy Raimi is famous for. After her unwillingness to help an old gypsy woman, Christine Brown (Alison Lohman) experiences the unusual attack from the angry witch casting a spell on her. The movie oscillates between a supernatural horror and a farce making for an inventive, yet totally amusing thrill ride. Even though the ending happens to be predictable, "Drag Me To Hell" never fails to capture attention with its tour de force scenes depicting violent attacks of evil forces. The movie is campy, gruesome, frenetic and most of all supremely entertaining.

title: Of gypsies who suck and refreshing horror movies...
review:
First of all - I am a huge fan of horror movies. I have heard a lot of "Drag me to hell" and finally I bought my own copy of this movie.

The Spanish intro (especially because of my Spanish, that is not that well and I hadn't put on my glasses, so even reading to me was kind of hard... ) has been a little confusing and in the next few minutes we get to know Christine who is just lovely. But in the cruel world she can't make it through with all of her neatness - at least it seems like it.

The movie is kind of ironic (especially in the end, when everything turns out to be different as expected). There are no real shock effects and the fight between the gypsy and Christine is hilarious... Yes, it has been disgusting (especially the toothless sucking on her chin), but it has just been kind of funny.

"Drag me to hell" is not the typical horror movie and in my point of view more likely a comedy - but in a good way. It did not scare me one bit, but you sympathize with the main character and hope that everything turns out good... but in the end you get a reasonable truth.

title: Bank employee becomes fatally cursed by gypsy as a result of rejecting, for opportunistic reasons, her request to postpone eviction
review: I really liked this one by former Boy Wonder Sam. In the Netherlands it got some really good reviews in the so-called quality newspapers and I looked forward to seeing it. Once again Raimi succeeds in taking the genre not too seriously in an intelligent fashion. As such the comparison with 'Tales from the Crypt' is worth a second thought. Of course, that's just my fairly humble opinion. Even funnier, several times he ridicules the 'shockproofness' of certain strong (moral) convictions. Not too worry, at times DMtH is scary as well. I found the opening sequence not the most interesting part of the movie, but it served a purpose. Well worth a try!

title: Literally the worst movie ever
review: This movie, literally was the worst compilation of trash that I have ever seen. It made the Movie THEY look like a cinematic masterpiece. From the jump this movie was horrifying in all the wrong ways. There was a point in the movie in which I thought that not only was it horrible, it was also offensive to all five of my senses. The music and the acting, were actually the scariest parts of the "movie". However the worst part of this cinematic pile of crap, was that I will never get the time back that I wasted watching it, and that is something that will haunt me forever. Unlike the awesome half second cgi skulls or the 90 year old woman who apparently was some sort of Gypsi-Bad Ass that was able to put curses on ridiculous objects. I certainly I hope I never run into her or she will curse my belt buckle or possibly my tooth brush or maybe even a small piece of paper that was ripped from a receipt. Do yourself a favor and never watch this movie you will be disappointed and might find yourself a little dumber when it is all said and done.

title: Sam Raimi has made his "Jaws: The Revenge"
review: So, this movie sucks I don't know why it has such a good mark on IMDb, my guess is that people get dumber by the day. It's not scary at all, it's not even funny, its retarded and you shouldn't watch this movie if you don't want to lose 2 hours of your time. about the movie: it's predictable, you don't care about the freaking characters you actually might root with that demon, and what about that demon?!?!? since when is Lamia a goat????!?!?!?!? I checked it out and she was supposed to be a freaking nymph ...you know the chick from Hercules the TV series, the one with the tail that used to stone people, but never mind that! Its actually quite connected with jaws the revenge, I used this analogy in response to some butt-hole that said that "Sam Raimi made his jaws" so like I said is connected: first the name "Lamia" in Greek means "large shark", at some point Lamia makes the exact same sound like the freaking shark made in jaws: the revenge, he uses suspense and it shows us very little of the demon but we feel its presence by the freaking vomit and crap in every second, ah yeah at some point the main character stuffs something into the mouth of the villain, and the list goes on... now to sum this in a question and to quote a man who's work I appreciate "WHAT WERE THEY THINKING??!??!?!?!?!??!?!?!?!?!???!?!?!"
